utterances: So what was the reaction to his win?
Let's return now to Afghanistan and NATO's agreement to begin reducing troop levels there and return control of security to Afghans in 2014.
NATO leaders emphasized they're not leaving Afghanistan altogether.
The Western alliance will remain in place after that date to provide military assistance and training for Afghan forces.
NPR's Quil Lawrence is in the Afghan capital and joins us for a view of how Afghans might view(ph) the talks in Lisbon.
Quil, thanks for being with us.
Good morning.
And how are Afghan leaders looking at this NATO meeting?
I think Afghan military commanders and government ministers, they seem to be on the same page as the generals and the NATO officials here.
For the first time since 2001, I think they're all feeling like they finally have a decent shot.
They've got enough U.S.
support, enough soldiers on the ground.
They have enough attention from the White House.
Of course, that's a tacit admission that the first seven or eight years were something of a long, wasted opportunity.
Many of them will say that if this sort of effort had been applied back in 2002, 2003, the problems then were much smaller.
They're aware of the fatigue among donor nations, especially those that have taken casualties here, but I don't hear much concern about other NATO countries.
They're mostly worried about the U.S., whether the U.S.
is going to, is going to stay.
And can you give us any insight into how regular Afghan citizens might be viewing this debate now?
Well, I find that Afghans outside the government or that aren't working with the Americans are living in an absolutely completely different reality from the one that I hear described by U.S.
generals, by NATO officials, by congressmen and U.S.
senators who come here.

For example, down in Kandahar, where they certainly have seen fierce fighting and killed many, many Taliban fighters down there, but at the same time villagers down there have been evicted from their homes by the violence.
They see that their homes are now - and their fields are still so littered with Taliban landmines and booby traps that the U.S.
military has actually had to bulldoze or sometimes rocket their houses just to clear them.
And they certainly aren't feeling any sort of a peace dividend.
I don't get a lot of optimism in my talks with them.
They're wondering if this is just a normal winter break in the fighting and it's going to come back just as fierce.
The Afghans I talk to here in the capital, they just don't see the gains that people are talking about.
They have trouble traveling around the country.
It's less safe that it's been in the past.
They find that the government is still overwhelmingly corrupt and many of them I talked are trying to leave the country.
Might they reflect that the picture the U.S.
is presenting at NATO meetings and elsewhere is just a little hopeful?
Exactly.

I think that they see since the summer and since the new team arrived under General Petraeus, there's been a very steady and strong message of cautious optimism, and I think many of them can see that that was on the way to the Lisbon summit.
Many of them have commented that when you talk to these people on the eve of a NATO summit, you're certainly going to hear a very clear message.
And let me ask you about the state of readiness of Afghan security forces.
What estimates do you hear, do you gain from your reporting, as to when they might be able to take control of large areas of the country?
Well, the good news is that rates of attrition seem to be down.
You still have a lot of soldiers going AWOL, but - you know, from very fierce fighting.
That's understandable.
But they say the recruiting goals are being met.
I just actually spoke with a friend who's a translator for the Marines down in Helmand and he says he's very impressed, that the army, the Afghan army has improved quite a lot.
But the question really is when they'll be able to take the lead, and that seems a very long way off.
First off, before they'll be able to plan and lead missions on their own - it'll be a few years, they say, before that will happen.
And then if you watch the number of helicopters that American troops use to supply themselves with food and water, the Afghans have none of that capability.
It will be a long, long time.
And another insight from the Afghan point of view: Why would President Karzai tell the Washington Post that he has such great reservations about the U.S.
strategy just before this meeting?
Well, NATO officials said that that certainly wasn't helpful to them, and in some ways they see that President Karzai's still having it both ways.

In private, his ministers and his aides can praise the military progress and say this is going great; in public he can go with the anti-American flow and he can condemn these night raids in Afghan homes and continue making peace overtures to the Taliban.
NPR's Quil Lawrence in Kabul.
Thanks so much.
Thank you.
This is Talk of the Nation.
I'm Neal Conan.
We're broadcasting today from the Knight Studio at the Newseum, Washington, D.C.'s newest museum devoted to journalism and the news business.
After the long, sometimes bitter primary campaign, a sizable fraction of Senator Hillary Clinton's supporters remain angry and resentful.
At the Democratic National Convention in Denver last night, she thanked them and asked them to move on.
I want you to ask yourselves, were you in this campaign just for me, or were you in it for that young Marine and others like him?
(Soundbite of cheering)
Were you in it for that mom struggling with cancer while raising her kids?
Were you in it for that young boy and his mom surviving on the minimum wage?
Were you in it for all the people in this country who feel invisible?
Well, I think that some of what you find is the ""I'm not racist, but"" argument.
You know, I'm not racist, but that person over there.
And we also, again, on our show, ran some tape of a woman who basically told Senator Obama that Africans were responsible for slavery and don't lecture me as a white woman on racial issues.
That said, there are also a lot of other fault lines.
There are ways in which Senator Clinton had a more centrist record or at least more centrist rhetoric than Senator Obama, if only by a hair.
And I think that comforted some people.
So the racial issue is one thing and the political issue is another.
Thanks very much for the call, Carolyn.
Let's see if we can go now to - we'll go to Mary.
Mary is on the line with us from St. Louis in Missouri.
For some, Hillary's speech was an eloquent call to unite behind Barack Obama, others remain unpersuaded.
We'll talk about reactions to her speech, whether the message extended beyond the convention hall and we want to talk about the historical context.
Senator Obama argues we're in a post-racial era past the battles of the 1960s, others disagree.
In that same context, are we post-gender?
We want to hear from you on this.
What did Senator Clinton's candidacy mean for women's rights and feminism?
Email us talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
We'll get comments from members of the audience here at the Newseum as well.
We begin with Farai Chideya, the host of NPR's News & Notes.
She's been covering the Democratic National Convention at the ground level and joins us now from the NPR's headquarters at the DNC in Denver.
Nice to have you on the program.
So delighted.
And what was the feeling last night during Senator Clinton's speech?
You know, I have been there for just days and nights seeing people arrive and it was so packed last night.
It was unbelievable.
It may not be INVESCO where you're going to have 75,000 people, but it was as packed as it's going to be.
And some people were there just to see what she would say and some people were there in tears, literally, because the person that they thought would be the first female president is not going to be.
Well, she won more votes than anybody who did not win the nomination of her party, and more states too.
A very close-run campaign as it turned out.
Last night, after months, after it was apparent that Senator Obama was going to win the nomination and Senator Clinton would not, do you think she sold the deal to her supporters?

Some people say yes, who you talk to, some delegates say yes and some say no. I think it depends on how passionate they are about Senator Obama as a figure who represents an equally important icon - this idea of the first black president.
Some of the people who feel that way think that she didn't quite go far enough in stressing that her criticisms of him during the campaign were, say, unfounded.
But you've got Joe Biden who was also a competitor, dropped out much earlier of course, and he said things about Obama.
So, I expect tonight, of course that he will backtrack a bit more.
But some people think that she didn't go quite far enough.
Most people seem satisfied, who I talked to.
And Clinton supporters, how did they break out on this?
Well, you know, I talked to some very interesting women and this brings up the issue of race.
After the speech last night, I went and just went up to groups of women, particularly one group of white women from New York and North Carolina.

And the woman from North Carolina really was adamant that not she, but many people she knew who were Clinton supporters, were not going to vote for Obama and some of them actively campaigning now for McCain in that battleground state.
The one from New York said, ah, you know, we're happy about this but sometimes, you just think at least couldn't she be vice president?
The African-American women from Texas, delegates from Texas, one of them only 21 years old, basically were like, eh, it's all good.
Let's move on.
It's interesting, during her address last night she made a direct appeal, you'd have to think, the way she couched it, to African-American women.
How do we give this country back to them?
By following the example of a brave New Yorker, a woman who risked her lives to bring slaves to freedom along the Underground Railroad.
On that path to freedom, Harriet Tubman had one piece of advice: if you hear the dogs, keep going.
If you see the torches in the woods, keep going.
If they're shouting after you, keep going.
Don't ever stop.
Keep going, if you want a taste of freedom, keep going.
And that of course had to have a lot of resonance for African-American women.
It was definitely an appeal directly to African-American women, but also to try to bridge that divide of what some call intersectionality, when gender and race collide.
Which, you don't have to be a woman or black to see that there are differences between how black women and white women or non-black women see this.
In fact, in an odd sense, as I talked to people, including people who were Native American delegates, I talked to a woman from the Pueblo Nation in New Mexico.

It seems as if in some ways there was a divide more between white women and non-white women in the sense that all the women of color I spoke with, no matter what color that was, really identified with the racial issues as much as or more than gender, and the reverse was true for white women.
Did you feel that those women of color resented being put on the spot - choose between your color and your gender?
Some of them have, but more of the people I spoke with, including some people we brought onto our show a couple of days ago, really resented the idea that history could be erased.
In the sense that black women had to go through a three-stage movement to get the right to vote.
First you had literally the Emancipation Proclamation which said black people are citizens and human beings.

Then you had the women's suffrage movement which meant that black women technically had the right to vote but then not until the civil rights movement really did most black women, think of Fannie Lou Hamer, have the right to shape American politics.
So there has been a very different path to political empowerment for black women than there have been for most other women in America.
And some people feel that history was not stressed enough.

Email us talk@npr.org.
We'll begin with Carolyn.
Carolyn with us in Akron in Ohio.
Hi.
I really loved Hillary's speech last night, especially when she said, were you in it for me or were you in it for - and then she gave those examples.

And Hillary, I think, did a wonderful job.
It's not about, oh, I'm taking my jacks and going home because, you know, you're not playing the way I want to play.
It's supposed to be about everyone.
It's - again, I can understand people's anger.
I feel Hillary was given, you know, the - she had the sexist comments made and I was angry, too.
But I cannot, in good conscience, support John McCain.
I just can't.

Farai Chideya, I wonder, when you talked to that woman again from North Carolina who said that - maybe not her, but some people she knows would abandon the Democratic Party and vote for John McCain this time around because of the way this campaign turned out.
Did they respond to those points?
Hello.
How are you today?
I just want to say the phenomenal speech that Hillary Clinton gave last night was awesome.
It is - at first my vote was going to be no for Barack.
I am leaning more towards him now and I think Thursday will gap - bridge that gap for me.
Mary, what in particular in Senator Clinton's speech last night made you think that?
I think when she said that you just keep moving on.
It was when she said how Harriet Tubman said, if the dogs are behind you, keep going.
And it just - it was a force that made me feel that yes, we need to do this in order to change what is happening in this country because it's not going to get any better.
And will you be listening tomorrow night when Senator Obama speaks?
Almost definitely.
That is the time when I will definitely make my final decision.
I was totally against up until last night.
I am leaning towards his direction as of now.
Mary, thanks very much for the call.
Appreciate it.
